data.title: Shotgun Shooting World Competitions
data.text:
Shotgun shooting at the Olympic Games

Since 1968, women were allowed to compete shooting alongside the men. In 1996, the program was segregated for the shotgun events also.

(?) or /? means tie breaker unkown.

1. 1896 not competed 2. 1900, Jul 15 - 17 Paris FRA 3. 1904 not competed 1906, Apr 26 Athína GRE 4. 1908, Jul 08 - 11 London GBR 5. 1912, Jun 29 - Jul 04 Stockholm SWE 6. 1916, May 28 - Jun 03 Berlin GER (canceled due to World War I) 7. 1920, Jul 22 - 24 Antwerpen BEL 8. 1924, Jul 06 - 09 Paris FRA 9. - 14. 1928 - 1948 not competed 15. 1952, Jul 25 - 26 Helsinki FIN 16. 1956, Nov 29 - Dec 01 Melbourne AUS 17. 1960, Sep 05 - 09 Roma ITA 18. 1964, Oct 15 - 17 Tokyo JPN 19. 1968, Oct 18 - 22 Ciudad de México MEX 20. 1972, Aug 27 - Sep 02 München FRG 21. 1976, Jul 18 - 24 Montreal CAN 22. 1980, Jul 20 - 26 Moskva URS 23. 1984, Jul 29 - Aug 04 Los Angeles USA 24. 1988, Sep 18 - 23 Seoul KOR 25. 1992, Jul 28 - Aug 02 Barcelona ESP 26. 1996, Jul 20 - 27 Atlanta USA 27. 2000, Sep 16 - 23 Sydney AUS 28. 2004, Aug 14 - 22 Athína GRE 29. 2008, Aug 09 - 16 Beijing CHN 30. 2012, Jul 29 - Aug 06 London GBR 31. 2016, Aug 07 - 13 Rio de Janeiro BRA 32. 2021, Jul 24 - Aug 02 Tokyo JPN

2021: The IOC postponed the Olympic Games to 2021 due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Shooting was originally scheduled on 2020, Jul 25 - Aug 03.

2000 - 2012: The top 6 shooters in the qualifying round moved on to the final round. There, they fired on additional 25 targets. The final result is the addition of qualifying and final score. Ties were broken by shoot-offs on single targets until the tie was broken.

2016: The top 6 shooters in the qualifying round (75 targets) moved on to the semifinal, qualifying scores did not carry over to the final rounds. In the semifinals, every competitor had 15 targets (only one shot). A table was established where the first and second fought for the gold medal, while the third and fourth - for the bronze medal. In the Gold and Bronze medal matches every shooter had 15 targets (only one shot) again. Ties were decided by shoot-offs on single targets until the tie was broken.

Since 2020: The top 6 shooters in the qualifying round (125 targets) moved on to the final round without taking into account the qualification scores. There, they fired additional (max. 50) shots. Every five shots the lowest-ranked shooter is eliminated beginning from shot 25. Only the last two competitors fired the shots 41 - 50.

1900 - 1906: 20 targets; Ties were decided by a shoot-off of another 20 targets.

1908: 80 targets

1912 - 1924: 100 targets

1924: Ties were decided by a shoot-off of 10 targets.

1952 - 1984: 200 targets; Ties were decided by a shoot-offs of 25 targets until the tie was broken.

1988 - 1992: 200 targets; The top 6 shooters in the qualifying round moved on to the final round. There, they fired on additional 25 targets. The final result is the addition of qualifying and final score. Ties were decided first by the total of the final. If this is still a tie by shoot-offs on single targets until the tie was broken.

1996 - 2012: 125 targets; The top 6 shooters in the qualifying round moved on to the final round. There, they fired on additional 25 targets. The final result is the addition of qualifying and final score. Ties were decided by shoot-offs on single targets until the tie was broken.

2016: The top 6 shooters in the qualifying round (125 targets) moved on to the semifinal, qualifying scores did not carry over to the final rounds. In the semifinals, every competitor had 15 targets (only one shot). A table was established where the first and second fought for the gold medal, while the third and fourth - for the bronze medal. In the Gold and Bronze medal matches every shooter had 15 targets (only one shot) again. Ties were decided by shoot-offs on single targets until the tie was broken.

Since 2020: The top 6 shooters in the qualifying round (125 targets) moved on to the final round without taking into account the qualification scores. There, they fired additional (max. 50) shots. Every five shots the lowest-ranked shooter is eliminated beginning from shot 25. Only the last two competitors fired the shots 41 - 50. Ties in the Gold medal shooting were decided by an single shot shoot-off.

Since 2020: The top 2 mixed teams in the qualifying round (every shooter fired on 75 targets) moved on to the Gold medal match, and the 3rd and 4th ranked mixed teams competing on the Bronze medal. There, every pair fired on additional 50 targets. In case of a tie each team member fired on 1 target in every round until the tie is broken.

1968 - 1984: 200 targets; Ties were broken by shoot-offs of 25 targets until the tie was broken.

1988 - 1992: 200 targets; The top 6 shooters in the qualifying round moved on to the final round. There, they fired on additional 25 targets. The final result is the addition of qualifying and final score. Ties were decided first by the total of the final. If this is still a tie by shoot-offs on single targets until the tie was broken.

1996 - 2012: 125 targets; The top 6 shooters in the qualifying round moved on to the final round. There, they fired on additional 25 targets. The final result is the addition of qualifying and final score. Ties were decided by shoot-offs on double targets until the tie was broken.

2016: The top 6 shooters in the qualifying round (125 targets) moved on to the semifinal, qualifying scores did not carry over to the final rounds. In the semifinals, every competitor had 16 targets (as doubles). A table was established where the first and second fought for the gold medal, while the third and fourth - for the bronze medal. In the Gold and Bronze medal matches every shooter had 16 targets (as doubles) again. Ties were decided by shoot-offs on single targets until the tie was broken.

Since 2020: The top 6 shooters in the qualifying round (125 targets) moved on to the final round without taking into account the qualification scores. There, they fired additional (max. 60) shots. Every ten shots the lowest-ranked shooter is eliminated beginning from shot 20. Only the last two competitors fired the shots 51 - 60.

2016: IOA = Independent Olympic Athletes: The team was composed of Kuwaiti athletes who competed under the Olympic flag, as the Kuwait Olympic Committee had been suspended by the International Olympic Committee (IOC) for the second time in five years due to governmental interference.

Shotgun shooting World Championships

Shotgun shooting World championships were held under the aegis of FITASC before 1951. In some cases, together with the UIT World Championships.

1910: 100 clay pigeons; The tie was decided by a shoot-off on single targets until the tie was broken.

1929: 3x100 clay pigeons on three days

1930: 100 clay pigeons; distance 15 m; with stand handicap, i.e., the best shooters so far had to shoot from the most difficult of the three available ranges. The tie was decided by a shoot-off on single targets until the tie was broken.

1931 - 1937: 3x100 clay pigeons on three days

1934 - 1938: The ties on medals were decided by a shoot-off on 20 targets.

1938: 3x200 clay pigeons on two days

1939 - 1967: 3x100 clay targets on three days

1969 - 1991: 200 clay targets; The tie was decided by (since 1977 max. 3) shoot-offs of 25 clay targets.

1986 - 1991: 200 targets; The top 6 shooters in the qualifying round moved on to the final round. There, they fired on additional 25 targets. The final result is the addition of qualifying and final score. Ties were decided first by the total of the final. If this is still a tie by shoot-offs on single targets until the tie was broken.

since 1993 125 targets; The top 6 shooters in the qualifying round moved on to the final round. There, they fired on additional 25 targets. The final result is the addition of qualifying and final score. Ties were by shoot-offs on single targets until the tie was broken.

2013 - 2015: The top 6 shooters in the qualifying round (125 targets) moved on to the semifinal, qualifying scores did not carry over to the final rounds. In the semifinals, every competitor had 15 targets (only one shot). A table was established where the first and second fought for the gold medal, while the third and fourth - for the bronze medal. In the Gold and Bronze medal matches every shooter had 15 targets (only one shot) again. Ties were decided by shoot-offs on single targets until the tie was broken.

Since 2017: The top 6 shooters in the qualifying round (125 targets) moved on to the final round without taking into account the qualification scores. There, they fired additional (max. 50) shots. Every five shots the lowest-ranked shooter is eliminated beginning from shot 25. Only the last two competitors fired the shots 41 - 50.

Only 2022: The top 8 shooters in the qualifying round (125 targets) moved on to the finals without taking into account the qualification scores. The finals consist of Ranking Match 1 and Ranking Match 2, composed of 4 athletes each and the Medal Match, composed of the 2 winners from each Ranking Match. In the ranking matches the shooter with the lowest score was eliminated after 15 shots. After further 10 shots the best two shooters of each group qualified for the medal match. In the medal match they fired max. 35 shots. After 15 shots and 10 shots resp. the lowest-ranked shooter is eliminated. Ties were decided by shoot-offs on single targets until the tie was broken.

1929 and 1931: The results of the best four shooters from the days two and three came into account (200 clay pigeons each).

1933 - 1937: The results of the best four shooters from all days came into account (300 clay pigeons each).

1938: The results of the best four shooters from all days came into account (200 clay pigeons each).

1939: The results of the best three shooters from all days came into account (300 clay pigeons each).

1947 - 1949: The results of the best four shooters from the first two days came into account (200 clay pigeons each).

1949 - 1954: The tie was decided by a shoot-off of 25 clay pigeons each shooter.

1950: scoring: 250 clay pigeons each?

1952 - 1958: The results of the best four shooters from the first two days came into account (200 clay pigeons each).

1959: The results of the best three shooters from the first two days came into account (200 clay pigeons each). Possible only unofficial?

1962 - 1967: The results of the four shooters from the first two days came into account (200 clay targets each).

1969 - 1974: The first 150 clay targets of each shooter came into account.

1975: The first 100 clay targets of each shooter came into account.

1977 - 1991: The first 150 clay targets of each shooter came into account.

since 1993 125 targets

2009 - 2019: The tie was decided by comparison of the last series of 25 shots etc. each shooter (in parentheses).

Only 2022: The best 2 teams in the qualifying round (75 targets each shooter) promoted to the Gold medal match and the next 2 teams to the Bronze medal match. Number of targets in the final: Up to 5 series of 5 targets each series. During each series, each team will shoot 15 targets. Maximum 25 targets each athlete (75 targets each team). After each series of 5 targets the team with the highest number of hit targets out of the total score of 15 targets, will receive 2 points and if the results are equal, then each team will receive 1 point. The team that earns 6 points first, wins the match. If at the end of the 5th series the two teams have the same number of points, then the winner will be decided by a shoot-off. When the first designated athletes of the two teams finished shooting on station 1, if the tie(s) is(are) not broken, the same procedure will continue on station 2 with the 2nd designated member of each team shooting etc.

1967 - 1975: The tie was decided by shoot-offs of 25 clay targets.

1986 - 1991: 200 targets; The top 6 shooters in the qualifying round moved on to the final round. There, they fired on additional 25 targets. The final result is the addition of qualifying and final score. Ties were decided first by the total of the final. If this is still a tie by shoot-offs on single targets until the tie was broken.

since 1993 125 targets; The top 6 shooters in the qualifying round moved on to the final round. There, they fired on additional 25 targets. The final result is the addition of qualifying and final score. Ties were decided by shoot-offs on single targets until the tie was broken.

2013 - 2015: The top 6 shooters in the qualifying round (125 targets) moved on to the semifinal, qualifying scores did not carry over to the final rounds. In the semifinals, every competitor had 16 targets (as doubles). A table was established where the first and second fought for the gold medal, while the third and fourth - for the bronze medal. In the Gold and Bronze medal matches every shooter had 16 targets (as doubles) again. Ties were decided by shoot-offs on single targets until the tie was broken.

Since 2017: The top 6 shooters in the qualifying round (125 targets) moved on to the final round without taking into account the qualification scores. There, they fired additional (max. 60) shots. Every ten shots the lowest-ranked shooter is eliminated beginning from shot 20. Only the last two competitors fired the shots 51 - 60.

Only 2022: The top 8 shooters in the qualifying round (125 targets) moved on to the finals without taking into account the qualification scores. The finals consist of Ranking Match 1 and Ranking Match 2, composed of 4 athletes each and the Medal Match, composed of the 2 winners from each Ranking Match. In the ranking matches the shooter with the lowest score was eliminated after 20 shots. After further 10 shots the best two shooters of each group qualified for the medal match. In the medal match they fired max. 40 shots. After 20 shots and 10 shots resp. the lowest-ranked shooter is eliminated. Ties were decided by shoot-offs on single targets until the tie was broken.

1958 - 1967: The results of the four shooters from the first day came into account (100 clay targets each).

1969 - 1974: The first 150 clay targets of each shooter came into account.

1975: The first 100 clay targets of each shooter came into account.

1977 - 1991: The first 150 clay targets of each shooter came into account.

since 1993 125 targets

2002 - 2013: The tie was decided by comparison of the last series of 25 shots etc. each shooter (in parentheses).

Only 2022: The best 2 teams in the qualifying round (75 targets each shooter) promoted to the Gold medal match and the next 2 teams to the Bronze medal match. Number of targets in the final: Up to 6 series of 2 doubles each series. During each series, each team will shoot 12 targets. Maximum 24 targets each athlete (72 targets each team). After each series of 2 doubles the team with the highest number of hit targets out of the total score of 12 targets, will receive 2 points and if the results are equal, then each team will receive 1 point. The team that earns 6 points first, wins the match. If at the end of the 6th series the two teams have the same number of points, then the winner will be decided by a shoot-off. When the first designated athletes of the two teams finished shooting on a double, if the tie(s) is(are) not broken, the same procedure will continue with the 2nd designated member of each team shooting etc.

1975: 100 clay targets

1977 - 1991: 150 clay targets

1993 - 1995: 125 targets

since 1997: 75 targets

2002 - 2017: The tie was decided by comparison of the last series of 25 shots etc. each shooter (in parentheses).

Only 2022: The best 2 teams in the qualifying round (75 targets each shooter) promoted to the Gold medal match and the next 2 teams to the Bronze medal match. Number of targets in the final: Up to 5 series of 5 targets each series. During each series, each team will shoot 15 targets. Maximum 25 targets each athlete (75 targets each team). After each series of 5 targets the team with the highest number of hit targets out of the total score of 15 targets, will receive 2 points and if the results are equal, then each team will receive 1 point. The team that earns 6 points first, wins the match. If at the end of the 5th series the two teams have the same number of points, then the winner will be decided by a shoot-off. When the first designated athletes of the two teams finished shooting on station 1, if the tie(s) is(are) not broken, the same procedure will continue on station 2 with the 2nd designated member of each team shooting etc.

1962 - 1967: 100 clay targets

1969 - 1974: 150 clay targets

1975 - 1991: 200 clay targets

1989: 200 targets; The top 6 shooters in the qualifying round moved on to the final round. There, they fired on additional 25 targets. The final result is the addition of qualifying and final score. Ties were decided first by the total of the final. If this is still a tie by shoot-offs on single targets until the tie was broken.

1993 - 1995: 125 targets, Ties were decided by shoot-offs on single targets until the tie was broken.

1993 no World Championship (only 13 shooters)

1997 - 2011: 75 targets; The top 6 shooters in the qualifying round moved on to the final round. There, they fired on additional 25 targets. The final result is the addition of qualifying and final score. Ties were decided by shoot-offs on single targets until the tie was broken.

2013 - 2015: The top 6 shooters in the qualifying round (75 targets) moved on to the semifinal, qualifying scores did not carry over to the final rounds. In the semifinals, every competitor had 16 targets (as doubles). A table was established where the first and second fought for the gold medal, while the third and fourth - for the bronze medal. In the Gold and Bronze medal matches every shooter had 16 targets (as doubles) again. Ties were decided by shoot-offs on single targets until the tie was broken.

Since 2017: The top 6 shooters in the qualifying round (75 targets) moved on to the final round without taking into account the qualification scores. There, they fired additional (max. 60) shots. Every ten shots the lowest-ranked shooter is eliminated beginning from shot 20. Only the last two competitors fired the shots 51 - 60.

Only 2022: The top 8 shooters in the qualifying round (125 targets) moved on to the finals without taking into account the qualification scores. The finals consist of Ranking Match 1 and Ranking Match 2, composed of 4 athletes each and the Medal Match, composed of the 2 winners from each Ranking Match. In the ranking matches the shooter with the lowest score was eliminated after 20 shots. After further 10 shots the best two shooters of each group qualified for the medal match. In the medal match they fired max. 40 shots. After 20 shots and 10 shots resp. the lowest-ranked shooter is eliminated. Ties were decided by shoot-offs on single targets until the tie was broken.

Since 2018 qualification 125 targets

1989: 100 targets as 50 doublets

1990: 200 targets as 100 doublets; The top 6 shooters in the qualifying round moved on to the final round. There, they fired on additional 25 doublets. The final result is the addition of qualifying and final score. Ties were decided first by the total of the final. If this is still a tie by shoot-offs on single doublets until the tie was broken.

1991 - 2011: 150 targets as 75 doublets; The top 6 shooters in the qualifying round moved on to the final round. There, they fired on additional 25 doublets. The final result is the addition of qualifying and final score.

1994 - 2009: Ties were decided by shoot-offs on single doublets until the tie was broken.

2013 - 2015: The top 6 shooters in the qualifying round (150 targets as 75 doublets) moved on to the semifinal, qualifying scores did not carry over to the final rounds. In the semifinals, every competitor had 30 targets as 15 doublets. A table was established where the first and second fought for the gold medal, while the third and fourth - for the bronze medal. In the Gold and Bronze medal matches each shooter had 30 targets as 15 doublets again. Ties were decided by shoot-offs on single doublets until the tie was broken.

2017: The top 6 shooters in the qualifying round (150 targets as 75 doublets) moved on to the final round without taking into account the qualification scores. There, they fired additional (max. 40) doublets. Every five doublets the lowest-ranked shooter is eliminated beginning from doublets 15. Only the last two competitors fired to the doublets 31 - 40.
